channel.title: What are you working on right now?
channel.description:
Tell us about your current game design project. Choose just one, even if you're working on more than one. Choose the one you most want to tell us about, whether it's currently at the conceptual stage, final polishing, or anything in between.
Tell us whatever you like, but definitely these three things: * The elevator pitch * Why you're excited about it * What your hopes are in relation to it
Thread rule: no unsolicited critiques or "that sounds a lot like this other game" posts.

item.title: What are you working on right now?
item.dc:creator: @TrayMitchell
item.description:
@TrayMitchell wrote:

Yeah i have dreamed of creating something interesting. Esepecially i was interested in mobile apps, but frankly i don’t have enough skills for doing this, so i try to get from various sources, like Youtube. I even tried to enter some professionals courses and this was in vain. I always liked those apps where you can play casino games and even placing bets like melbet registration https://melbetonline.pk/registration/ and wanted to create something like this…always, maybe i need more time, who knows

Read full topic
item.source: What are you working on right now?

item.title: What are you working on right now?
item.dc:creator: @ex1st
item.description:
@ex1st wrote:

I recently launched a game jam, and really hope that some of you take an interest. I also posted it on the Gauntle here: 2nd CoinSides Adventure Sparks Game Jam Cheers.

The jam is for 1500-word modules that should fit in just about any running campaign. A bit like a side quest or extra bit of lore, all centered around a coin. There are prizes and I’m working hard to make it fair and fun.

item.source: What are you working on right now?

item.title: What are you working on right now?
item.dc:creator: @Markfullyarmoured
item.description:
@Markfullyarmoured wrote:

Heya! First time poster after long time listener to Jason Cordova on various channels.

I’m working on a game called KNIGHT. People are Arthurian style knights, questing about the land for the High Queen of Avalon. The game involves collab style gaming, where players are creating a map filled with adventure points between them before going back to their knightly house and doing various things. It’s also got a generational aspect - knights only get about ten adventures before they retire, to which you play your heir.

It’s rules light, with a mix between procedures as in Blades in the Dark and a player facing version of Into the Odd. I was influenced strongly by Trophy’s consequences, but have yet to integrate anything with it. Had a few playtests and ran a full campaign of 30 sessions with my after-school kids.

The process has taught me the pain and joy of layout design and youtube tutorials for InDesign :D.

If people are interested I have a webpage and a discord .

Hope to chat, here or elsewhere!

Read full topic

item.title: What are you working on right now?
item.dc:creator: @DeReel
item.description:
@DeReel wrote:

I’m working on streamlining Rev.Ivre, polishing “Here we used to fly” playbook & attraction and a space-opera adaptation of “microCore”. And still translating the travel guide to Alatria.
I’m thrilled with Rev.Ivre because it’s a drama workshop in disguise. I hope to learn workshop animation know how.
With Used to fly and Core, the feeling is more serious and open. These are about collaboration, wrapping my head around another person’s project and crafting high ludic potential material. A new territory for me, working on Setting, a bit daunting, the wind of adventure.

Read full topic
item.source: What are you working on right now?

@RolistesPod_Kalum, FYI, over on RPGGEEK.COM there was a little poll and discussion of a list of games ranked as Must Try rpgs from a random podcast. Paris Gondo was on that list. No one else had heard of it , so I gave it a shout of support. I mentioned it in a forum thread regarding fun rpg “filler” games as well.

item.title: What are you working on right now?
item.dc:creator: @BLaST-Oz
item.description:
@BLaST-Oz wrote:

rabalias:
  • The elevator pitch

decKarnage!
A game based on randomness, silliness and fluffy Violence!
Did you lave “I hate Fairyland” by Skottie Young?
Can you quote at least half of the Munchkin text cards?
ChaOSR is your middle now? (What? That’s impossible)
DecKarnage is your game.
Based on drawing a card from an innovative totally randomized deck, can you loot the treasure before the VIP will arrive to kill you?

rabalias:
  • Why you’re excited about it

It’s our (me and my wife) first kickstarter.
Also we worked so hard in the past year to study how to write a full accessible game.
… and, Fluffy Violence is our passionate love!
(But we despite violence, just to be clear)

rabalias:
  • What your hopes are in relation to it

The KS is founded, now we need to solidify the rules and make a lot of playtest. Also we hope to write something that people wants to play and are happy to play, something quick, funny in few pages. Looking at it now it seems really hard to do all of it but we are hard workers.

Read full topic

item.title: What are you working on right now?
item.dc:creator: @Fenris-77
item.description:
@Fenris-77 wrote:

So I was scrolling through my many, many, folders of PDFs and abortive writing projects and came across the Brindlewood Bay mystery I started for the writing contest and then promptly forgot about. Amazingly, I just kind of finished the first draft without having to gird my loins or it feeling like work (which is why a lot of the projects I put down don’t get picked back up). Anyway, if anyone wants to give it a read, here’s Death of the Author: da PDF

Read full topic
item.source: What are you working on right now?

item.title: What are you working on right now?
item.dc:creator: @DeReel
item.description:
@DeReel wrote:

I have written most of my Shonen puzzle game in one-page modular mini games. I am now working on the most meta part, that’s how to weave character arcs stepping stones (think Jenna Moran’s Chuubo or Nick Wedig’s Baba Yaga) and external conflicts.

I’m excited because it’s a Grail to me: linking external and internal conflict in a symbolic way (exact analogy would kill the interpretative game). Few games do this, and my “formula” promises to be accessible enough and leave sufficient cognitive space to do fun things with the ext/int symbolic relationship.

I hope to hold that promise. I just passed the major obstacle. The problem I see from here is first to pick apart the advice from the rules (eg: stakes setting and raising when how and why). And second to keep it simple, although character progression, harm, and other important subsystems all want to converge into this play phase: Conflict. This will take some analysis (feels like playing Tetris with subsystems). But writing-wise, this means I have too much ideas and they’ll keep coming. All problems I love having.

Read full topic
item.source: What are you working on right now?
